specs/train/approved/glance/cluster-awar.message: Suggestion: change this to "each glance-api node is" (to match the "is" on line 43)
Can you say a bit more about what you have in mind here?
I added paragraph to the proposed solution section.

Can we have a deployment + configuration scenario explained.

For example suppose I have 3 glance-api nodes running then how should I configure servcer_tags config option in glance-api.conf?
Sure, that's definitely something for the docs patch for this.
i think maybe "not required to be unified" is more accurate?  (What I mean is the default case would be all glances are in the same group, but for edge cases we might want to partition the nodes.)

If it's configured it's unlikely to be unified. There is always one default queue configured to avoid the mechanism getting stuck. So unless this needs to be separated to smaller units than all, there is no need to configure this.
approach (sorry, missed it first time through)

Three questions:

What's the default value for server_tags? I guess it could be an empty topic, but it might be better to have an actual value.

I guess all nodes will both publish to and subscribe from all the server_tags in their config file?

Could you give some more detail to your "edge site 1" example?  What I mean is, if you have some normal glance nodes and some edge nodes, which ones get 'ES1' in their server_tags.

What it comes down to, is I get how this will work for something like POST v2/images/{image_id}/import -- the node receiving the request publishes "hey import image_id" and each consumer checks to see if they have that image_id in their stage, and if so, they do the import.  At that point, how does the info get back to the original node to return a 202, and how will the node know to return a 404?  I guess that's the same problem for how to get the list-cached-images response from an edge site.  Or maybe I'm not thinking of this the right way.  In any case, a bit more example will help me understand how you see this all hanging together.

Like mentioned above, there is default value if it's not configured and all nodes can be always addressed with the "glance" tag. This is to avoid the whole shebang getting totally stuck.

The tags are only for the topics the node is listening. They will publish to topics based on the request coming in from the api. So your edge nodes would get "ES1" tag and your central nodes would get "CDC" tag etc.

Rabbit handles the responses with return queue for specific messages so that we get the info funneled back. These are just disposable queues that gets autogenerated with uuid as name (directly as rabbit documentation instructs to handle these scenarios). There is timeout for the response, so if none of the nodes in the queue gives green light for having the data, we will return failure to the client.

I think you should include some of this in the spec, particularly the business about using the disposable queues.

Also, from what you say here, the server_tags tell a node what topics to subscribe to.  But how does the publisher know what to include so that the exchange will publish to the appropriate queue?  I'm missing something here.

Sure I include the rabbit MQ tutorial [0] into the next revision.

I think the part what you're missing here is that Usage of the queues is really dependant of the feature that will utilize this ground work. So for example the included image import will just call the topic all nodes are subscribed to by default, plain and simple.

Mostly we do not quess what the user might want but expect the request having what we need if user wants something else than default behavior. Say we implement single point cache management API we expect the Tags being documented per deployment. We cannot just quess how the site layout is and how the operator wants to define their topology. The user needs enough information to include the server tag in the request so (s)he can request Glance to precache image X in say Edge Site Y which nodes are tagged with "ESY" tag. The responding node will just use the callback queue (this is box standard Rabbit thing explained in the tutoria [0]) for that message to get the response back.

List cached images again doesn't even need to have tag specified in the request and we can safely default to the queue to all nodes to return the results from the all nodes. Or based on the tags set up in the deployment they can be as granular or simple as the operator wants without Glance needing to worry about any of that, just know which tags to subscribe and publish to the tags in request.

Getting the base as usable as possible makes it really problematic to include any definite model to this spec. Specially as we do not want to make tight limitations on the framework we need to battle against when those features utilizing this is being implemented.

In short at this point we really don't need to know which topics we might need to send the message to. That will be defined by the request coming in from user and any possible defaults will be defined by the feature utilizing this.

[0] https://www.rabbitmq.com/tutorials/tutorial-six-python.html

So each node will subscribe to a queue for each of the tags it's configured for, right? Presumably these will need to be fanout queues, so that if you send a message to that queue, it goes to every subscriber instead of the default which is one-of, round-robin.
Yes, that was the idea behind this.

Can you describe what you're actually going to do with/via rabbit once you have it?

From reading the rest, I gather that you're planning to basically proxy calls from one worker to the intended one over rabbit, is that right? Like, if someone calls import on worker 7, but the image was staged on worker 3, then we'll contact worker 3 over the bus and tell it to do the thing that was asked of 7, and then report the result to the caller, is that right? If so, why not just have them talk directly to each other over http? Meaning, why not have worker 3 call to the same API on worker 7's direct interface?

I can also provide some experience from nova, where we do a lot of this indirection, and can say that you need to be mindful of timeouts, because the one acting as a proxy will have its own timeout to wait for the child to respond, but the caller will have its own, which may be shorter. Note behaviors like doing an RPC call where the message bus goes down will result in an infinite hang (from the caller's perspective) if the connection to the bus is lost, until it comes back.

That is the part we have been trying to sort out _how_ do we actually handle it. Last idea we were investigating was to have "dry run" test function in the API that would check if it can actually fulfill the request and if so respond it's hostname as potential executor. As we discussed during the PTG I think your approach will solve a lot of the issues what comes to the image-import part (as long as we expect the API nodes being able to do http requests to eachother). I think the fanout rabbit queues will be best used for stuff like "All nodes on site A, precache this image" or "everyone, what images you have in your cache" etc. where we expect response from multiple nodes rather that try ot find the one that can process specific request.

How will the other workers find each other? In the import case above, if the import comes into me as worker 7, how do I know that I need to talk to 3, and what 3's address is (either over the bus or direct-http)? In nova, each service registers itself in a table, at least for the purposes of calculating message topics. Is that already present in glance (I haven't looked, but would not have thought so)? Presumably there needs to be some accounting in the import process to say "and this is waiting on worker 3" so that worker 7 knows who to delegate to, right?
Correct we do not have anything like that in the DB. thus we were thinking of discovering the possible executor via the initial fanout message for each request.

If you took the above http direct approach for things that need to be delegated to specific workers, then it would be trivial to have a boolean flag of "to proxy or not". If proxy is enabled, then one worker proxies the call to the other worker internally. If proxy is disabled, it returns a 3xx redirect to the actual URL of the desired worker. In some cases, you would not want to expose your raw workers to users, but in others, it would be massively more efficient to do so (i.e. in an edge case where proxying through a worker at the central location only to ask one at an edge site to do something would be quite indirect).
This doesn't sound like a bad idea at all.

specs/wallaby/approved/glance/cluster-aw.message: I would say "direct" or "forward". The _user_ is "providing" the request.
I don't think "remarks" is the right word here, but I'm not sure exactly what is. Perhaps "total independence without any _notion_ of possible other nodes" ?
I would say "message" here, to clearly indicate the difference between the HTTP request that caused us to do something from the "messages" we send over RPC to take some action.

This is literally the first mention of this in the spec here. I really would like to see more detail in the Proposed Change section about _what_ is being done. I vaguely know what you're proposing because we've discussed it previously, but right now this spec would be pretty mystifying to people I think :)

I think we discussed using oslo.messaging now that you're back to a much more conventional use-case for rabbit, so I assume this needs to change to use the proper terminology (RPC server and RPC client)?

However, splitting this from the caching use-case (which I believe is the only one currently proposed, right?) makes this a little weird, as that spec/effort is really where that stuff needs to be done.

Perhaps this spec should just plan to set up an empty server and client structure, upon which things like the caching spec can build?

Are you still planning on doing this? I thought the plan for the MQ part of this was now just to support the caching stuff, which would be less about forwarding API calls over RPC and more about making RPC-specific actions for things like the caching? Perhaps just remove this bullet and save the actual work items of using this for the caching spec?

Fanout messages need to be casts, which means you don't really get any sort of failure indication, except for a failure to deliver the message to rabbit or something. The only way you could know about per-node success would be to send the fanout and then expect every node to send you a directed message back, which kinda defeats the point of a fanout in the first place. Even still, that would be something likely specific to the caching use-case and not something about the generic functionality you're describing here.

What sort of functional and integration tests will come out of this? Since I think the first use of RPC via rabbit will be the caching stuff, I'm not sure what you'll really be able to test here.

I guess my point is...it's maybe a little hard to see this being a fully standalone effort from the caching stuff - maybe the best thing to do would be to just roll the MQ bits of this into the caching effort where it can be described more concretely?
This looks to me like a single URL that was intended to be wrapped. I think you want to put these into a list so they clearly show up as separate items.

deployment/neutron/neutron-sriov-agent-c.message: This service will NOT be enabled for "switchdev" mode (SR-IOV Offload).

I think the proper way to have this condition is:

sriov_config_remove_result is changed

'is' makes it a test, whereas currently the condition is checking if the string is populated (I think)

The check should be whether the value of the 'changed' key in the dict 'sriov_config_remove_result' is True or False. If the sriov_config.service is present, then the 'changed' should be set to True. This condition should be fine.

Fair point on the casting side of thing, but you'll notice that the page describe using the test 'is success' rather than checking a value.

Either way, I've not objected to this - it was just a suggestion. There's no negative vote here.

> the page describe using the test 'is success' rather than checking a value.

Yes, I did try 'succeeded' with samples. It checks if the task is failed or succeeded, which does not implicate the whether the task has changed something or not. Task can succeed, even when the changed is false. 

>  it was just a suggestion

You are most welcome. It gave me an opportunity to read the docs, understand it with examples.

That makes sense. I haven't noticed the 'changed' and 'skipped' possbilities for result check. I will apply this change in a follow-up which I will be doing for ovs offload. Thanks for the explanation (with patience).

Then the condition should be:

  when: sriov_config_remove_result['changed'] | bool

Otherwise it will not evaluate it as a boolean, but instead evaluate it as a string.

But, the correct way to evaluate the results of a task is to use the test format as previously mentioned.

> > the page describe using the test 'is success' rather than
 > checking a value.
 > 
 > Yes, I did try 'succeeded' with samples. It checks if the task is
 > failed or succeeded, which does not implicate the whether the task
 > has changed something or not. Task can succeed, even when the
 > changed is false.

Yes, the way to do it with the test syntaxt would be:

  when: sriov_config_remove_result is changed

This can be done with any task result, any of ['success', 'succeeded', 'fail', 'failed', 'skipped', 'changed'] and perhaps others.

I'll try again without osd-devices. I've not gotten a clear explanation on why we're using this (it's copy/pasta here but we have osd-devices='/dev/test-non-existent' in other ceph charms for some reason. Maybe icey knows.

I know the answer to that.  It is a regression test against a bug that we fixed a long time ago with regard to directory based OSDs.   The bug was that specifying a non-existent directory would cause a hook error.

So, we should keep testing non-existent directories for Ceph releases where directory OSDs are supported.

And, we should stop specifying that for Nautilus and later.

Note that the disabling of bluestore and direct IO options are also there only to support directory based OSDs and should be removed.

The other Ceph charms have the osd-devices configuration options set like that just to validate that the charm handles non-existent directories and stuff like that.

Since this test is validating RBD Mirroring, we don't need to re-validate that bit.

.pre-commit-config.yaml.message:
With pre-commit you cannot have version ranges, only pinning is supported. It does not matter how often the upstream tool makes releases, it is up to you to decide how often you want to bump linter versions, usually the answer is is more of "when needed". bumping version is automated by running "pre-commit autoupdate" which looks for new tags and modifies the file, so you do not need to do it manually.

The answer to the other question: nope flake8 does not usually breaks on release, is not very active now. Still, it can happen and we do not want to pay the surprise price.

specs/approved/anaconda-deploy-interface.message:
Hmm... and vendor_passthru are also not deploy interface based.

Heartbeat + some sort of status maybe?

Will investigate if we can switch to using heartbeat mechanism. Anaconda doesn't have an API, so the conductor can't talk to anaconda. All communications have to be initiated from the anaconda ramdisk.

Some of these features are supported in Ironic already, like creating md arrays. However: the setup of md devices requires admin access to the node. So, how about mentioning that this enhancement will address use cases where the *user* (as the instance creator and in contrast with the admin) would like to configure specific disk layouts with md/lvm?

It supports both UEFI or BIOS or both based on the kickstart file provided by the user. So the kickstart file validation needs to be done in the conductor for a specific boot mode. And that information needs to be provided.
This is not a limitation, is it?

The default template will automatically generate partitions for both UEFI and BIOS boot modes. This is achieved using 'autopart' mechanism. However custom templates should be validated for correctness on the conductor. I have not decided on how much validation we should do on the conductor level. If the customer does not create a EFI partition on UEFI boot, anaconda installer would complain and fail the deployment regardless if we validate it or not.
How aboout installing the packages? where do we host them?Can we also make a point about the installation here or at some other appropriate place?

Installing packages using %packages section of the kickstart template is out of scope for this SPEC. This SPEC only supports OS image deployment using 'liveimg' kickstart command. I will call this out explicitly if i have not made it clear already.
Isnt the kickstart semantics differ from Anaconda version to version? Would it be useful to support instance level kickstart template?
Correct, kickstart versions differ between anaconda releases. The default template will be generic enough to work with multiple anaconda versions both RHEL/Centos7/Centos 8 and Fedora >=31

Presuming the kickstart file also supports network configuration and the user tries to configure tenant network, the PUT call is made through the tenant network.If the tenant network is other than the provisining network which is used for bootloading the images, this will fail unless there is a route to provisioning network from tenant network. We need to call out this limitation explicitly in the documentation.

ironic/conductor/base_manager.py.message: FWIW, this should be exiting with the drivers table populated. I guess we're trying to just push the conductor being marked online before the drivers are running.

Ideally, I'd prefer us to register each hardware type separately. I don't have any strict objections against your approach, but I have a feeling that registering per type is cleaner.

I think the crux of the problem that BMO faces is that some drivers are not fully usable even though they are shown in /v1/drivers? If so, registering each hardware type automically will solve it.

I'd slightly prefer it to be fixed in BMO then. Do you think it's possible?

I still think it's useful to register a hardware type complete in ironic, just not so sure about registering everything. It's a minor problem, of course, I won't block the patch based on that.

> I think the crux of the problem that BMO faces is that some drivers are not fully usable even though they are shown in /v1/drivers? If so, registering each hardware type automically will solve it.

No (although I did think this at one stage), the problem is that drivers are registered one at a time, once the BMO sees the first one it starts creating nodes but the one it needs might not be there yet. This isn't necessarily an ironic bug but registering all drivers together ensures BMO doesn't prematurely use one that isn't registered.

The BMO fix will also need a similar fix a terraform provider that I'm told would be more complicated. We now have a workaround in metal3 to deal with our problem so there is no urgency. I'll push an updated version of this patch so we can see what the finished patch might look like.

setup.cfg.message:
Any reason to make these separate commands rather than simply parameters of the 'address group set' command? e.g.

  address group set --address ADDRESS --address ADDRESS ... ADDRESS-GROUP

I agree with Stephen, that in other cases those are standalone resources and thus treated separately. I.e. we do not have "subnet add dns_nameserver 1.2.3.4".

Is there potential limit on addresses in the group? I agree management of 10+ entries via "set/unset" might be sub-optimal, but with chosen CRUD design it falls exactly here. Otherwise we need to start treating addresses as standalone meta entities ("address group address list", "address group add address"), since even listing 20 addresses as property of the group is also not optimal.

I think adding separate 'router add/remove route' command was the wrong decision and should be fixed, to be honest. OSC's purpose is not to map to the APIs exactly. It's to provide a consistent interface to an OpenStack cloud. I noted that the address is not a standalone resource because this is the crucial distinction used to assess whether we can use this pattern or not [1].

I don't think the fact that these are different APIs under the hood is an issue. A similar example would be the 'flavor set' command. This allows you to both set the flavor description and add the flavor to a project, and while the former uses the '/flavors/{flavorID}' endpoint, the latter is done via a different '/flavors/{flavorID}/os-flavor-access' endpoint. These are different APIs yet the same command is used for both: 'openstack flavor set'. Similarly, consider the 'server set' command. This actually uses *five* different APIs under the hood, but it's all exposed via the same command.

Given Artem is in agreement here, I really do feel this is the way to go. While I don't think 'router add/remove route' is probably worth correcting now, if you'd like to make that consistent (via 'router set --route') I'd be happy to help.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/contributor/humaninterfaceguide.html#command-structure

My understanding for set command is it is more about specifying the state of a property like name and description. If using it for addresses then it'd hard to provide the full address list  when it gets long. Technically I think we can still set/unset to specify the address delta, but using separate explicit add/remove commands should be better for the readability and that also follows Neutron's convention like network_agent_add/remove_router in L413 below.

I've thought on this more. While we do have examples of '<resource> add <subresource>', such as 'network agent add router' and 'server add port', I don't think this is the same as what we're doing here. Those things are proper resources in their own right. They can exist without the parent resource, i.e. you can create a router separately from a network agent, or a port separately from an instance. Addresses, as used here, are not. They're attributes of the main "address group" resource, akin to a description or metadata properties. I think they should be set as such.

Also, all the other add/remove commands use singular, e.g. 'server add port' rather than 'server add ports' because you can only add one sub-resource at a time.

Could we change this to remove the 'address group (add|remove) addresses' in favour of 'address group (set|unset) --address'?

I followed the example of neutron router add/remove route when designed the server API and CLI https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/commit/dba57c85d5536369d600ae98599c08b921713bd5 So in that example, route is an attribute for router but also uses the action add/remove in API and CLI. The main reason was because set/unset to specify the whole route state was not convenient for users and error-prone at server side. Address group is similar to that case as it is designed to hold many addresses (no limit is set yet) and want to support atomic address change. Currently for Neutron server side and SDK we already set to use the action endpoints: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/address_group.py#L70-L71 and https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/network/v2/address_group.py#L54So I'd really like to keep the CLI aline with that instead of changing to set/unset. I have changed the command to use singular 'add/remove address' as you suggested. Artem and Stephen please let me know what do you think. Thanks!

When an existing machine type is listed for the instance in sysmeta or image metadata then I wanted to block operators moving between these underlying types for both SHUTOFF and SHELVED_OFFLOADED instances.

When a machine type isn't already listed in the instance sysmeta or image metadata then I was going to allow operators to set whatever they want (with the caveat that they shouldn't move between underlying types outside of a rebuild documented) as there's no sane way for us to check config defaults where the instance was previously running without forcing these commands to run on the computes etc.

Assuming the instance doesn't have a hw_machine_type image property set then it's going to default to whatever is configured for the arch when we unshelve. Given the spec is trying to allow deployment tools, operators and devs to change these defaults going forward then that's likely going to result in the underlying machine type changing (pc-i440fx to q35 etc).

I'd rather document this, add the nova-status command, possibly add another nova-manage command to validate a given machine type on a compute allowing operators a way of sanity checking before applying changes and leave it at that for now.

Presumably we also want SHELVED to behave like SHUTOFF, right? The instance will be in a different state, but it's basically the same behavior if they unshelve without offloading. Unless there's some reason not to allow it, I think people would expect it to work in SHELVED as well.

actually python3 requests rpm is not available in CentOS7 base repos, so with $(package_manager) ==  "/usr/bin/yum" condition we ensure that requests is installed from pip only on CentOS7 systems and not on CentOS8/rhel8 etc. we can install those from epel though but that would add an additional dep and we should avoid dep on epel. Is this doc complete?

This is noted on line 52 above.

The undercloud-ipa-install.yaml playbook is designed to set up everything before installing the undercloud. It creates the undercloud host, sets up the service, and fetches the keytab. You don't need to configure the undercloud to enroll itself.

While this case is convenient, we can't assume it's reasonable for most production deployments to give TripleO administrative access to FreeIPA. The undercloud-ipa-install.yaml playbook assumes you can provide it administrative rights.

The deployer might not have any administrative rights to IPA, making the installation process contingent on obtaining a one-time password from someone who does. We attempted to address this by writing separate playbooks that FreeIPA admins can use (documented here), if they want an automated way of generating the host, service, and privileges needed by the undercloud. Once they generate the password, the deployer can configure the undercloud to do its own enrollment.

swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3request..message: just curious why you didn't change HashingInput to raise BadDigest? AFAICT this is the only place HashingInput is used

So HashingInput is only used for s3api requests -- but the point at which the exception is raised can vary considerably. Here it pops during the read(), still in s3api -- but it can *also* be raised down in the proxy-server app as we're reading chunks to send to backends. Now the BadDigest should still be an instance of swob.HTTPException -- so it shouldn't trip a 500 down there or something -- but it seems weird to be raising the s3-style 400 down in the proxy-server; I'm not convinced the middlewares between here and there will handle it appropriately.

Even if they do, the way s3api is written, it's expecting to translate swift responses to s3responses (over in s3request.py) and I don't think we have HTTP_BAD_REQUEST in our error map.

So keep in mind Deepak, when we said it would be useful for the playbooks to call out to shell scripts similar to what the openstack-helm gets do - what was meant here is self-contained shell scripts separate from the ansible job itself. I was incredibly disheartened to see a tweet like

https://twitter.com/VictorStinner/status/1299294981623078918?s=20

that seems to have been in response to flared tempers over the recent mess with telemetry or whatever.  

Anyone can git push/pull anywhere and that's not where time is spent these days.  It's developer effort put into everything around that; workflows, CI, CD, release pipelines, etc. etc.  

It's one thing to turn a blind eye to buliding workflows around github actions + travisci (running everything on aws and azure).  I'll be the first to admit these offer many wonderful things, and the relationships open source has with these companies is somewhat symbiotic; they need the open source eco-system as much as it needs them.  

But go so far as to attack a *truly* open source effort, where there's literally a few encoded API keys but *everything* else, soup to nuts is open for inspection, review and contribution -- I feel like there's a disconnect.

It used to be at the top, and it did not get through.

The idea of this rewrite is to answer the questions of people coming from GitHub, for which the "free software needs free tools" concept is a bit alien. So the idea is to first explain the differences, then add a few extra selling points for them to consider.

To get the point through, I feel like we need to get outside of opendev and write content for opensource.com or other publications that explain what we are trying to achieve here.

I might use the term "rebase" here because that's the git command while "squash" isn't, though I get your point.

Suggestion, although it's long:

When changes are requested developers squash (or in git terms "rebase") their change and submit a new revision.  The history of the change is kept in Gerrit, where reviewers can compare previous revisions to the currently proposed change.  Only the final change will be committed to the repository, leaving out the intermediate steps taken to refine the change.  The pure merge model includes these changes in the main commit history, but elides the surrounding review discussion or CI results that leads to new commits.  These intermediate changes -- changes that may have syntax errors, were rejected in review or plain didn't work -- pollute the code history with a lot of irrelevant code movement that is very difficult to follow when debugging.  While only the final result is committed, every commit has a link back to the Gerrit change where developers can find the full history of the change, including all relevant discussion leading up to it's commit.

Also, as much as I don't like the fact, "rebase" is a dirty word to many users. And really, we recommend an "amend but only rebase when necessary" workflow with Gerrit. Gratuitous rebases are disruptive to review as they make inter-patch diffs nearly useless.
Keeping it intact as I think "squashing" captures it in a more positive way
I saw your previous comment on not wanting to hide things; I still don't think it serves us to list why the service isn't as good as commercial offerings on the front page.
I reworded it to make it less like a drawback, and more like a difference that is worth it

Just like we don't have to deprecate ourselves; we should probably be careful about saying we are more advanced than github actions, etc.  for example, that has a bunch of "matrix" build features to run similar things on different platforms that we do not exactly have OOTB (but templates is a similar idea done differently).  What's more advanced is probably a matter of taste.

I would probably just mention as related work, if anything; and TravisCI seems an omission given it's widespread use.
Done

To me I'd leave this bit out.  As you say it's obvious and we don't need to harp too much about the perils of non-free software.  We are also very lucky, mostly probably through our pre-approval process for repos and general focus that we have not had to deal with abuse -- but we are not a sort of utopia where anything goes.

I'd prefer to keep it in.

Again this page is not directed to you (or anyone who feels like "uses free software" is enough of a justification). It's directed to a typical GitHub user, coming across Opendev for the first time.

99% of GitHub users don't see ANY problem with using it for open source development. I write that it /should/ be obvious, but it's REALLY not, except for us in our bubble.

So I think there is a definite need to harp. Everywhere and all the time. In any outward-facing explanation of Opendev. And this is a key one.

docker/gitea/custom/templates/home.tmpl.message: It's debateable whether your code host is really a "build requirement" for your software, and I've seen lots of people argue that the reason using those services is okay is because they're not required and are easily swapped for another host if terms of service change. Possibly a more compelling argument is that if you're building free and open software you hope people will use in place of proprietary alternatives, then choosing to rely on proprietary software and services when developing your software conveys by example that you don't actually value the free and open alternatives others like you are producing for those parts of the workflow/toolchain.

author.name: Jeremy Stanley
author.status: missing, presumed fed

docker/gitea/custom/templates/home.tmpl.message: Probably the confusion stems from common use of "build" or "built" to refer to the process of generating usable artifacts from source code (compiling, linking, bundling, converting...). The real point is that contributing to the project requires interacting with proprietary tools and services, even if the tools needed to "build" the project (compilers and related toolchain) have available and supported F/LOSS implementations the developers are using.
Maybe using "relies on proprietary code to be built" would convey the right nuance.

docker/gitea/custom/templates/home.tmpl.message: We don't actually develop the configuration management and automation around these with outside reusability in mind, and really don't have sufficient support bandwidth to assist others in setting up similar services. This is a departure from our prior efforts where we attempted to make things like Puppet modules we used reconsumable. We discovered that the time and effort involved in supporting configuration options or deployment scenarios we don't use ourselves in our implementations, worrying about downstream consumers who might be broken by non-backward-compatible changes requiring manual intervention, and so forth was eating a disproportionately large amount of our time. We serve as an example of how these services can be run together, but I wouldn't want to imply that the way we operate these services is easily reused and modified.
Good point, maybe I should get rid of that sentence completely. Or at least say "possible" rather than "easy".

Oops, I misspelled.

We don't have to assign the empty string in the out of if/else so, just as:

if policy and policy.sorting_method:
    sorting_method = policy.sorting_method
    read_affinity_sort_key = policy.read_affinity_sort_key
else:
    sorting_method = self.sorting_method
    read_affinity_sort_key = self.read_affinity_sort_key

It's python's magic.

The reason I'd prefer using if/else rather than using only if is to catch unexpected wrong behavior.

For example,  if we used if condition to overwrite some variables but we forgot to assign a variable like as:

sorting_method = self.sorting_method
read_affinity_sort_key = self.read_affinity_sort_key
if policy and policy.sorting_method:
    sorting_method = policy.sorting_method
    # Oh no, I forgot to assing read_affinity_sort_key
    # read_affinity_sort_key = policy.read_affinity_sort_key

That would work but would behave bad silently.

If we use if/else syntax instead of above like as:

if policy and policy.sorting_method:
    sorting_method = policy.sorting_method
    read_affinity_sort_key = policy.read_affinity_sort_key
else:
    sorting_method = self.sorting_method
    # Oh no, I forgot to assing read_affinity_sort_key
    # read_affinity_sort_key = self.read_affinity_sort_key

We absolutely can see an error in the invalid case and it will be able to remove silent error. 

Does it make you sense?
